Award.AwardTitle: A Full Lifecycle Approach to Understanding Adélie Penguin Response to Changing Pack Ice Conditions in the Ross Sea.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Ross Sea region of the Southern Ocean is experiencing growing sea ice cover in both extent and duration. These trends contrast those of the well-studied, western Antarctic Peninsula area, where sea ice has been disappearing. Unlike the latter, little is known about how expanding sea ice coverage might affect the regional Antarctic marine ecosystem. This project aims to better understand some of the potential effects of the changing ice conditions on the marine ecosystem using the widely-recognized indicator species - the Adélie Penguin. A four-year effort will build on previous results spanning 19 seasons at Ross Island to explore how successes or failures in each part of the penguin's annual cycle are effected by ice conditions and how these carry over to the next annual recruitment cycle, especially with respect to the penguin's condition upon arrival in the spring. Education and public outreach activities will continually be promoted through the PenguinCam and PenguinScience websites (sites with greater than 1 million hits a month) and "NestCheck" (a site that is logged-on by >300 classrooms annually that allows students to follow penguin families in their breeding efforts). To encourage students in pursuing educational and career pathways in the Science Technology Engineering and Math fields, the project will also provide stories from the field in a Penguin Journal, develop classroom-ready activities aligned with New Generation Science Standards, increase the availability of instructional presentations as powerpoint files and short webisodes. The project will provide additional outreach activities through local, state and national speaking engagements about penguins, Antarctic science and climate change. The annual outreach efforts are aimed at reaching over 15,000 students through the website, 300 teachers through presentations and workshops, and 500 persons in the general public. The project also will train four interns (undergraduate and graduate level), two post-doctoral researchers, and a science writer/photographer.

The project will accomplish three major goals, all of which relate to how Adélie Penguins adapt to, or cope with environmental change. Specifically the project seeks to determine 1) how changing winter sea ice conditions in the Ross Sea region affect penguin migration, behavior and survival and alter the carry-over effects (COEs) to subsequent reproduction; 2) the interplay between extrinsic and intrinsic factors influencing COEs over multiple years of an individual?s lifetime; and 3) how local environmental change may affect population change via impacts to nesting habitat, interacting with individual quality and COEs. Retrospective analyses will be conducted using 19 years of colony based data and collect additional information on individually marked, known-age and known-history penguins, from new recruits to possibly senescent individuals. Four years of new information will be gained from efforts based at two colonies (Cape Royds and Crozier), using radio frequency identification tags to automatically collect data on breeding and foraging effort of marked, known-history birds to explore penguin response to resource availability within the colony as well as between colonies (mates, nesting material, habitat availability). Additional geolocation/time-depth recorders will be used to investigate travels and foraging during winter of these birds. The combined efforts will allow an assessment of the effects of penguin behavior/success in one season on its behavior in the next (e.g. how does winter behavior affect arrival time and body condition on subsequent breeding). It is at the individual level that penguins are responding successfully, or not, to ongoing marine habitat change in the Ross Sea region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding changes in animal communities requires the observation of many individuals and documenting how their stories unfold over individual lifetimes. The most valuable information for understanding changes in communities of wild animals is gained when we’re able to identify individuals, and then observe them over time, but this important process can be very difficult to achieve when dealing with wild free-living animals. We can collect this kind of information by putting unique tags or marks on animals that allow us to tell individuals apart and then follow them through time documenting behavior and life history events (e.g., birth, death, reproduction). Long-term data sets based on this kind of information from marked individuals are even more valuable when the time span of the observations encompasses large amounts of variation in the environment and reflects at least the length of the study species’ lifespan - particularly when the exact ages of these individuals are known - because this provides an important context for understanding their life cycle. With these data, a wide variety of vital rates (e.g., survival, reproductive success) at the population level can be estimated and these data from wild populations can be used to understand the evolution of demographic parameters within a species (i.e. help us understand why species populations trend the way they do). 

This project collected long-term data on known-age Adélie penguins with known-breeding histories to investigate variation in survival relative to age and breeding status, the probability of breeding every year (i.e. breeding propensity), and the age of 1st breeding. We also examined the degree to which these rates can vary among breeding colonies, and their relation to annual variation in local and regional environmental conditions. We collected these data on three colonies of Adélie penguins that differ vastly in size (i.e. by orders of magnitude) during 1996-2019. Although our analyses to understand long-term demographic patterns continue, we’ve already learned a variety of important lessons. For example, we know that annual survival rates differ by colony, and by age, and by breeding status within colonies. Young birds prior to their first breeding attempt (pre-breeders) have the lowest survival rates, but survival increases with age up to about age 4 and/or the age at which a bird starts to breed (range: 3-14 years), at which point pre-breeders have higher survival rates than breeders of the same age through ~9 years old.  We found that breeding adults don’t breed every year, and in fact only 58%-78% of breeding individuals breed again in the following year. Birds that bred in a previous year, but are not currently breeding (i.e. non-breeders) had the highest survival across all age classes, suggesting that while breeding means “success” in one sense for an individual bird, it may come at a cost to their subsequent survival, consistent with prevalent life history theory. In general, success at raising one or more chicks during a breeding season improved with more years of breeding experience, peaking towards the end of a bird’s lifespan.

Survival rates did not differ by sex, but females recruited into the breeding population at a younger age then males, so given that breeders have lower survival than pre-breeders, the lifespan of females is shorter than that for males. In addition, survival differed by colony, with the lowest survival observed at the smallest colony (Cape Royds), intermediate at the largest colony (Cape Crozier) and highest at the medium-sized colony (Cape Bird). During the same time period, age-at-1st breeding was lowest (i.e. birds started breeding at younger ages) at the largest colony, and highest at the smallest colony. However on-going analyses suggest these patterns may have changed in the last 10 years, and it is not yet clear how the variation in these vital rates between colonies is resulting in vastly different population trends.  We now have 24 years of data on known-age individuals, and might just now be reaching the top end of the species’ life span in the wild. We continue to follow our known-age individuals at all three colonies to learn just how long they live, the oldest age at which they can breed successfully, and whether the smaller colony persists and the larger colony continues to grow in size. Gathering this information on the Adélie penguins of the Ross Sea, Antarctica, will allow us to understanding how climate change is affecting the population trends of this iconic species in a rapidly changing environment.
